title: Lycium berlandieri
text:
Lycium berlandieri is a species of flowering plant in the <a href="Solanaceae">nightshade family</a> known by the common name Berlandier's wolfberry. It is native to Mexico and the south-western United States from <a href="Arizona">Arizona</a> to <a href="Texas">Texas</a>.
This <a href="shrub">shrub</a> reaches up to tall. The roots may extend from the plant. It has spiny branches. It loses its leaves and becomes dormant during dry times. The bell-shaped flowers are solitary or borne in pairs. The fruit is a juicy red <a href="Berry%20%28botany%29">berry</a>. This plant's life span is 90 years on average.
This plant is characteristic of the flora of the <a href="Sonoran%20Desert">Sonoran</a> and <a href="Chihuahuan%20Desert">Chihuahuan Desert</a>s. It is rarely <a href="dominance%20%28ecology%29">dominant</a>, but it occurs in many types of desert habitat, including <a href="mesquite">mesquite</a> and <a href="saltbush">saltbush</a> <a href="plant%20community">plant communities</a>, creosote, grassland, prairie, and savanna. It can grow in desert salt flats and other saline habitats. It may invade grassland along with mesquite during the process of <a href="ecological%20succession">ecological succession</a>. In the Sonoran and Chihuahuan Deserts it grows alongside <a href="Fouquieria%20splendens">ocotillo</a> ("Fouquieria splendens"), <a href="Carnegiea%20gigantea">saguaro</a> ("Carnegiea gigantea"), <a href="Krameria%20parvifolia">range ratany</a> ("Krameria parvifolia"), <a href="Olneya%20tesota">ironwood</a> ("Olneya tesota"), <a href="Simmondsia%20chinensis">jojoba</a> ("Simmondsia chinensis"), <a href="Calliandra%20eriophylla">false-mesquite</a> ("Calliandra eriophylla"), <a href="Encelia%20farinosa">brittlebush</a> ("Encelia farinosa"), <a href="Jatropha%20cardiophylla">leatherstem</a> ("Jatropha cardiophylla"), <a href="Dalea%20formosa">feather dalea</a> ("Dalea formosa"), <a href="yucca">yucca</a>, <a href="agave">agave</a>, "<a href="Opuntia">Opuntia</a>" cacti, and <a href="acacia">acacia</a> species. In Texas it can be found in sandy <a href="Arroyo%20%28creek%29">arroyo</a>s and more saline areas alongside mesquite and <a href="Celtis">hackberry</a>.
Many birds and rodents consume the fruits of the shrub. <a href="Gambel%27s%20quail">Gambel's quail</a> live in habitat where the shrub is common, and they use it for cover and nesting.
Native Americans consumed the fruits and used the plant medicinally.
